review_title: It really depends on your department
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Important mission to end extreme poverty and the ability to work on some incredible issues, events, and televised shows. Your co-workers are incredible, caring and always there to help.
cons:
Leadership, specifically middle management, can be toxic with no openness to change or listening to lower-level employees. No opportunity to move up or grow due to manager's fear of losing their seat at the table and in high-pressure situations (such as events) it can feel like people have open reign to treat others poorly including yelling, 'blame-gaming', and hostile emails. Each department is run silo'd and not cohesively creating a disjointed feel to an organization with the same mission.  

It seems like such a mixed bagged on your experience from a department by department basis dependent on your manager.

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good experience and growth opportunities
cons: Low salary and too many hours of work

pros: It’s uplifting and collaborative. You get a chance to work across the world.
cons: Pay and upward mobility are limited

pros: The organization means well, the mission is positive.
cons: The organization is ran by a central office and leaves little freedom for international offices to set their own paths to succeeding.

pros: World wide team that coordinate across time zones. Feel like i'm making a difference.
cons: none that I'm aware of

review_title: Changing the world for the better is hard work
pros:
My experience working at Global Citizen was very positive - it was unquestionably the highlight of my career to date. Not a day went by where I didn't feel pride in my work and my contributions to the organization as a whole. 

It was a dream to be surrounded by amazingly talented colleagues and inspirational leaders who are deeply and genuinely dedicated to the mission. All working together towards a shared goal: ending extreme poverty by 2030. 

Making a positive impact on the world requires work and dedication - it's a massive mission - but that mission is the glue that connects and unites every employee at GC. 

During my interview conversations it was clearly communicated to me that the hours would be demanding at times - especially during festival season - so I was not surprised by the periods of increased workload. 

During those periods, the organization brought in some of the most talented contractors I've ever had the pleasure of working with and learning from. Leadership supported staff as much as possible, and when I needed additional resources, all I had to do was ask for help and they made it happen. 

The world of events can be intense, but I personally loved the adrenaline and camaraderie among the team leading up to our festivals - those experiences gave me the greatest feeling of purpose, along with some truly special friendships.
cons: Global Citizen has to scale pretty quickly leading up to events, so there is a natural revolving door of talent. But even though it can be tough to see so many people cycle in and out, many ex-GC still come back and work events long after leaving.

review_title: fast paced and action based advocacy group
pros: help build the movement to end extreme poverty
cons: extremely fast paced of work

pros:
Your co-workers will be some of the best people you will meet. 
30 days of PTO.
The ability to work remotely.
cons: Do you want to work for a non-profit and feel like you are doing good for the world? Do not move forward. Do you want to work in the entertainment business (events, festivals, tv shows, broadcasts)? Then continue on. Most of the reviews on here are fake as you can tell from the one-sentence responses but high ratings. For a company fighting for equity, the pay gap within the organization is astronomical. Some people will go years without a promotion or a pay raise while others will consistently rise up and be compensated for such. There are too many office politics that it becomes hard to do your job. The company has become a revolving door with many leaving before their 1-year mark.

review_title: Difficult to move up and low salary
job_title: Global Marketing in New York, NY
pros: Great team and great people
cons: Very low pay for the amount of work that is expected

review_title: Exciting high profile work with a message.
job_title: Art Director in New York, NY
pros: Good people, exciting work, ethical consciousness a core value of the organization.
cons: Quick changes, rush work often. Many stakeholders to get approvals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great colleges, great mission, no day is the same
cons: Expectations, constant rushing, and odd priorities

review_title: Some great people, but too many broken pieces [and people]
pros:
- People! Talented, sharp, globally-minded 
- Some leadership is rock-solid
- Some of the culture: relationship-building, progressive(ish) 
- Exposure to interesting and relevant work - including partner orgs and other industries
cons:
- People! Too many cooks in the kitchen, some genuinely bad, ego-driven eggs.
- Organizational mission/values/strategy: There's something mildly evangelical and pyramid-scheme-y about the place... and, very "white superhero" kind of vibes and people in power. Not very strategic, very reactive.
- Most of the culture: Some rude and disrespectful personalities and people in leadership positions; lacking process and structure; often too many cooks in the kitchen; way too many unproductive meetings; often "wheel spinning" for an indecisive C-Suite; claims to be flat, but is quite hierarchical (which is fine, but confusing when not really flat or democratic); staff size is too big for management, and management itself needs a lot of training; culture often brags about overwork... not very holistically healthy.

review_title: Ambitious but could do better with career path help

pros: Global events and well resourced. Extremely well connected
cons:
Top heavy
Used for corporate career furtherance - hence high turnover of staff

pros: You learn a lot quickly from super talented people.
cons: Not a lot of structure or organization.

cons: Working remotely can be a challenge for team building.

pros: An organization of true believers - very committed, earnest and respectful. Always responsive to employee concerns and work hard to address issuses.

pros: Great people and good travel

pros: Working in concerts and getting the behind the scenes can be fun. You are also working in non-profit // social good industry to end extreme poverty...but..
cons:
If you look at how they make their money, and their sponsors, and you do some digging, you realize that they are in bed with the fellows who are not really living or working towards sustainable business models. 

The work environment is definitely toxic, stemming from the CEO. People are afraid to stand up to him, and say no; and he bends backwards to get money for the org to fund the concerts. The staff overall is very unhappy after the first year. The office politics are also pretty bad, and since it is a small place, it is much more challenging to navigate than a larger corporate environment.

pros:
Exposed to a variety of experience/i.e learn a lot
Can make great connections with other NGO's and corporates
Festival is a tremendous growth opportunity, lots of fun, and overall amazing experience
Some of the staff members are wonderful.
cons:
Upper management is totally unqualified to run this organization and are downright disrespectful to junior staff. CEO didn't know my name for an entire year.

CEO is completely obsessed with his image, has no regard for his staff and their growth trajectory, is inappropriate and socially awkward

Overall vision of organization drastically changes from time to time and there is ABSOLUTELY no transparency with partners/stakeholders and even staff.
Your work will become your life--you will bring your work on vacation and home.

Overall morale is low, lots of competition between co-workers, job security is a joke.

review_title: Impactful work, culture of empowerment, and ambitious mission
pros: The organization always puts impact first over merely raising awareness about a specific problem. As an advocacy organization it is not afraid to call out leaders who do not follow through on their words, nor will it water down its calls to action. It also has the ability - rare in the development space - to look at the macro picture of what truly needs to be done to change the systems that keep people living in extreme poverty.
cons: As a result of the organization's scale of ambition in achieving its mission,  work-live balance can become an issue. Management has recognized this, and is committed to improving the organizations' culture and great strides have been made over the last 18 months.

review_title: The toughest job you will ever love
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: People here work very hard but the work is inspiring.  When you hear the committments being made on stage and the lives effected by our work, it is hard to not feel proud.  While much of the work can feel like working for a for profit company:  marketing, design, content, HR, admin .. the organization is great at connecting it all back to the mission.  The policy team gives regular staff briefings and is always available to explain how the work relates to ending extreme poverty.
cons: The hours can be long and several times a year we produce live events including the big event in Central Park for 60,000 people.  Live events are stressful.

review_title: Strong team with a clear strategy. Room for more innovation.
pros:
I love working at GC. It is hard work, but we have real impact, and the team is intelligent, caring and passionate. 

The leadership and executive team seem open to new ideas, and are hiring staff to fill important roles, like HR.  

The 2019 campaign was a success. The plans for 2020 are exciting.
cons:
More investment is needed in technology and the App. The technology is good, but needs more investment to drive growth. 

As a campaigning organization there are periods where the work is consuming, and work/life balance can be a challenge. The shared services team have made progress in making the busy periods more manageable.

review_title: Enthusiastic, youthful, and positive change driven organization
job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
The most vibrant work community I've ever been a part of. Everyone is an integral part of the company, everyone's voice and contribution is valued, everyone knows each other by name, and interdepartmental coordination and partnership is key! The employee average age is very young, so there is a real youthful energy at GC. 

The best part about working at GC is the work you are a part of creates real, tangible change in the world. And everyone who works here is motivated to create that type of change.
cons: You will always be busy. There is never an "off-season". And since we are a global company, expect the off-chance of a call or meeting being scheduled at any hour of the day to accommodate international partners!

review_title: Big ideas, strong delivery, make your own impact
pros:
In 15+ years working on international issues, I’ve never seen an Organization with such a big ideas and a can do attitude. 

What the team are able to achieve - often without a huge amount of time or money - is remarkable.

There are a lot of incredibly talented people from a diverse range of backgrounds each using their strengths to build the movement and achieve policy wins.
cons:
Global Citizen doesn’t provide a huge amount of structure / process, which can make things frustrating for some staff who prefer clear rules. 

The all-consuming nature of really big events makes work / life balance hard in the month around each of them.

review_title: Still the worst place I've ever worked
pros: Never understood the appeal
cons:
-The majority of the staff are trust fund babies who don't mind getting paid $50K if they get to rub elbows with Chris Martin  

- I really can't think of a worse leader than the CEO - obsessed with himself and doesn't care about employees (unless they are hot girls, or related to someone rich/ famous) 

- Zero work life balance since many people live, work and hang out together.  If you aren't part of their 24/7 clique,  opportunities will slip through your fingers and there will be little room for advancement 

Half of the upper management is rude and abrasive while the other half goes out of their way to treat junior staff like they are invisible (echoing other comments on here where people will refuse to introduce themselves or learn your names - which is unacceptable for a small/mid size organisation

pros: Great mission and access to jump in and get things done.
cons: Poor management and continual lack of HR structure and support has led to mismanagement and leadership with poor management experience. Aside from the COO, most executives at GC have not had other significant working experiences.  The biggest issue  that is toxic to the organization is the total disempowering of diverse voices . GC leadership continually disrespects and disempowers black voices .

pros:
People are excellent (non-exec team)
Work is challenging
cons:
•misalignment of priorities against any values (or convenient ignoring of values as necessary by executives to push through decisions not based in any real strategy). 

•Lack of clarity and alignment to process, dictated by the whims of the CEO.

•No HR process. Complaints are handled inappropriately.

•Excessive favoritism (including and beyond promotions) leading to unfair pay scales and work-life balance for some, none for others. Pay scale differentiation is  based on opinions of the executives cherry-picking performance based on who they like and don’t, not on actual outputs. 

•Executive team makes on-the-fly decisions without input from their more qualified team leaders in addition to  meddling,  man-splaining and making and breaking false promises

•No resources given except to teams that bring in revenue.

•Excessive attention given to large events and not to the actual movement.

•Some teams beg for resources, others are flush with resources with payouts for resources dictated by who the CEO and executives think do the work for large scale events.

•Team asked to go well above and beyond to “make it happen” what would be considered acceptable or appropriate for personal safety, well being, morale.

•Shameless chasing of funding over building the movement and accepting funds from any brand, diluting any real impact. 

•Leaders on the team (who have far more experience) are regularly told how to do their jobs.
 
•Promotions handed out on a whim based on who can anticipate changing strategies before they’re formalised or even discussed with teams.

•Out-right about-faces and deceit about work output, promotions, staffing, events and projects by executive team.

review_title: Growing organization of passionate people who care about improving the lives of millions of people around the globe.
pros:
You get to work with a talented team on a vitally important mission--ending extreme poverty--and you get to have fun doing it. What's not to like?

It's definitely an ambitious organization. By this I mean they try are trying to accomplish a lot without a ton of resources. From top to the bottom, this means everyone is expected to bring their best effort and it shows in their results...it is  remarkable what this group has accomplished in a relatively short period of time of existance--pulling off concerts on 4 continents, building a huge digital advocacy platform, helping to raise hundreds of millions of dollars, and raising awareness around extreme poverty around the globe.

Working at Global Citizen was a rewarding experience and one that I will never forget.
cons: Not many, but the organization has certainly had some issues as a result of its rapid growth; the full-time staff more than doubled in the short time that I was there. The most noticeable problem was that strategy communications were sometimes spotty, though this was something I thought improved noticeably over the course of my employment. I feel like a greater investment in the Human Resources function would have helped the company with this problem and with communicating with the staff in general.

pros: I've been working at Global Citizen for just over a year and love it. It's inspiring to work with so many passionate people trying to make the world a better place. Super friendly team, employees are well looked after, great office culture with lots of opportunities to progress and learn quickly about all aspects of the organisation, plus amazing travel opportunities!
cons: Global Citizen has a startup feel - this can be both a positive and negative. Meaning the pace of change within the org can sometimes be rapid - which is not ideal for all. But this also provides lots of opportunities to get involved in new projects and help shape the direction of the organisation.

pros: - Some on the team are the most passionate people I've ever worked with
cons:
Just about everything else:

- No management structure. If you really like first time managers who care more about their own advancement rather then the health of their team, this place is for you!
- CEO is laughably out of touch and under-qualified to lead a team/project of this scope.
- Pay is woefully below industry average. Upper management seems to treat working there as privilege enough and pay to be icing on the cake. 
- If you have a title below Senior Manager, don't expect to be given the time of day.
- Sexism is RAMPANT, echo another writers' comment about the CTO. Not limited to him though by any means.
- While a good third of the team is very passionate/qualified, the other 2/3rds are there just to be close to celebrities and musicians. 
- High employee turnover: no thought given to retention.

review_title: Needs to grow up and find its direction, but good people and TONS of opportunity and access to amazing experiences
pros:
The independence one is given here is unlike anything I have ever seen. You're pretty much given a general objective and told to figure out how to achieve it. It can be pretty daunting and frustrating at times, and this place is definitely not for someone who needs to have their hand held, but the learning curve is super steep and it has been the source of incredible personal/professional growth.

Additionally, the Festival was the greatest day of my entire career. So much fun and such an awesome reward after all the hard work.
cons:
A lot of the Executive Management team. The rest of the staff is kept in the dark about the direction and priorities of the organization, which in the end, probably doesn't make a difference because they are constantly changing. The CEO is never around and you don't get the impression he really cares about his staff. I'm sure he does...but he needs to work on showing it. 

THAT SAID. There have been comments about sexism, in particular referencing the CTO. The two employees who wrote those comments left the organization very disgruntled. One of them had a very odd personal dislike for the CTO which he made apparent by spreading bizarre rumors.  Though I won't argue with a lot of their organizational comments, I am a woman - and a hardcore feminist - and I have never felt an ounce of sexism while working at GPP. NOTE: I am NOT the CTO ;)

pros: Value driven organization that actually puts mission first. If you want to be at a place where you can see and feel the impact your work has, this is it. The organization works with best in class artists, organizations and governments, and is in a league of its own in this regard.
cons: It’s a very fast paced environment, which is great for some, not so for others. It functions more like a start-up than it does an established charity. Something to note for future job seekers.

pros: Entrepreneurial, fast moving organization, strong mission focus, talented co-workers, fun
cons: Goes through extremely busy cycles of work, start up culture

review_title: Company withdrew job offer due to COVID-19
job_title: Senior Digital Campaign Manager in London, England
pros: The company runs some interesting campaigns and organises events globally for a good cause.
cons: Following a successful recruitment process, I was offered a job at the company's office in London. I handed my notice period, and just a few days before I was supposed to start my new job they withdrew the job offer due to COVID-19. I understand this is an unprecedented situation that may have affected this and other companies, but they literally left it to the very last minute to cancel my contract. I could have stayed with my previous employer and be put on furlough, so this obviously left me in a very vulnerable position. Just a few weeks until this happened, I saw in the news they had raised $7 Billion for COVID.

review_title: Great people, good culture, work is challenging but rewarding.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Some of the most hard working, passionate and dedicated people I have ever worked with. The staff are on the youngish side but very bright and thoughtful.
cons: Very busy especially during Festival season. Many people work exceptionally hard, but recently management has started to introduce more office social events and activities which has been good

review_title: Not all that glitters is gold...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, interesting people, easy commute/near most transportation, office location, independence, commendable mission, in-office events, music festivals and event perks.
cons: Pay is minimal while work is often overwhelming. Always “on the clock”- expect work texts and emails on nights and weekends. No internal accountability, weird and dingey office space, uncomfortable computer chairs (only upgraded to a decent quality if medically necessary). Complete lack of employee development and support services or materials which is vital in organizations that expect individuals to manage projects from inception to execution on a daily basis.

pros: An actual 9-5 in NYC. Free snacks. Great Soho location. Sounds great from the outside/looks great on paper, and bonus street cred for Global Citizen Festival tickets for (only your closest) friends. Can get some real work accomplished if you're a likable self-starter.
cons: Organization-wide lack of communication makes retention a challenge.

job_title: Project Management in New York, NY
pros: The organization is very unique; the mix of campaigning, media and content and the largest cause events on the planet create a drive for greatness I haven't found anywhere else.
cons: There are definitly some long days and nights around the big events.

pros: I was able to join the GC team in the midst of festival season. All teams worked collaboratively and tirelessly to meet their goals and objectives. The culture there is welcoming and you never have to feel afraid to speak up with any questions/concerns you may have. Great group of hard-working individuals with the passion for social change.
cons: None at this time.

review_title: Inspiring mission and enthusiatic young team
job_title: Editorial Intern in New York, NY
pros: Everyone I worked with and met at Global Citizen was kind, hard working, and eager to make a positive impact on the world. Rapid growth and creative energy in the office made for an exciting work environment.
cons: While I was there, it was clear that the organization had experienced rapid growth and it was still in the process of developing cohesive strategies across the office.

pros:
-Great work, really making a wonderful difference
-The festival is super fun
-Great opportunity for internships to turn into fulltime jobs
-Really fun bonding events, great coworkers
cons: -The CEO, while wonderfully passionate, is woefully under qualified to be running a business

review_title: Intelligent and hardworking team. Ambitious plans for the future.
pros:
The team are very focused on the mission and are working hard to achieve the organizations goals. 

The leadership team seem to be finding ways to grow the organization and its impact.
cons: It’s important for the organization to find ways to reinvent itself, and not become stagnant.

pros: Such a friendly and welcoming team. I would recommend this company highly. A talented group of people working so hard to make the world a better place which is really inspiring.
cons: Honestly nothing, everyone is great  and a fantastic team.

pros: Open work space environment, friendly co-workers, work on something that makes the world a better place
cons: Although the office is set up as an open space, perhaps the layout can be re-imagined for more interactions across departments

pros: A scrappy, start-up company where you have a lot of room to build and be creative.
cons: Lofty goals means lots of pressure to get it right all of the time.

pros: Great People. Interesting Events and Partners.
cons: Poor Benefits. Disorganized. Erratic. Morale.

pros: Great people, descent pay, comfortable work environment.
cons: Lack of communication and leadership. Not many opportunities for advancement within the company.

pros: Sense of community and enjoyable work
cons: Lack of Communication, lack of direction at times

felt appreciated
doing something that matters

pros: Fantastic cause. Well connected, tech savvy NGO.
